AOS: A. O. Smith manufactures gas and electric water heaters, boilers, and water treatment systems for residential and commercial use. Most sales come from North America, where plumbers, wholesalers, and retailers stock its brands. The Rest of World unit sells similar products, with China as the largest single market. The company earns revenue by producing these water heating and purification units and selling replacement parts and filters over their long life.
AYI: Acuity Brands designs LED light fixtures, lamps, and lighting controls for offices, factories, stores, and homes. Its Acuity Brands Lighting unit sells Lithonia, Holophane, and other fixtures through electrical distributors and contractors. The Intelligent Spaces Group offers sensors and software that collect building data and automate lighting, HVAC, and energy use. Revenue comes from manufacturing these lighting products and selling connected services and maintenance to building owners.
ADM: ADM buys corn, soybeans, and other crops from farmers around the world. It crushes oilseeds into vegetable oils and animal feed and mills grains into sweeteners, starches, and ethanol. The company also blends plant proteins, flavors, and probiotics for packaged foods and drinks. It earns money by processing crops at scale and selling these refined ingredients to food makers, livestock producers, and fuel companies.
APD: Air Products builds and runs plants that separate air into oxygen, nitrogen, and argon for steelmakers, electronics fabs, and food processors. It supplies hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and helium through pipelines, trucks, and on-site generators to refineries and chemical plants. The company also designs and sells cryogenic equipment and liquefied natural gas heat exchangers for energy projects. Profits flow from long-term gas supply contracts and merchant sales of industrial gases and equipment.
ALB: Albemarle mines lithium from brine and hard-rock deposits in Chile, Australia, and the United States. It converts the ore into lithium carbonate, hydroxide, and metal used in electric vehicle batteries and energy storage. The company also makes bromine chemicals for flame retardants, water treatment, and electronics, and sells refinery catalysts through its Ketjen unit. Profits come from selling these specialty chemicals under multi-year contracts to battery makers, industrial firms, and oil refiners.
ALLE: Allegion designs mechanical and electronic locks, door closers, and exit devices for homes, schools, and commercial buildings. Its Americas segment sells Schlage, Von Duprin, and other security products through distributors and retailers in the United States, Canada, and Latin America. The International segment offers similar hardware and software in Europe, Asia-Pacific, and the Middle East. Revenue is generated by manufacturing these access control products and providing related installation and software services.
AMCR: Amcor converts plastic resin, aluminum, and paper into flexible films, pouches, and bags that protect food, medical devices, and personal-care goods. It also molds rigid plastic bottles and jars for beverages, sauces, and home-care products. Engineers work with brand owners to design packaging that extends shelf life, cuts weight, and meets recycling rules. The company earns profits by producing large volumes of custom packaging and selling them under long-term supply agreements.
AME: Ametek builds electronic instruments that measure pressure, temperature, vibration, and power quality for aerospace, energy, and industrial customers. It also makes electromechanical motors, blowers, and precision motion systems used in medical devices and factory automation. The firm grows by adding new models and buying smaller technology companies that fit its product lines. Money comes from selling these instruments, spare parts, and maintenance services worldwide.
AVY: Avery Dennison makes pressure-sensitive labels, graphic films, and RFID inlays used on consumer goods, shipping boxes, and vehicles. Its Label and Graphic Materials unit coats paper and film with adhesives and sells rolls to printers and converters. The Retail Branding and Information Solutions unit supplies price tags, care labels, and radio-frequency ID tags to apparel brands and retailers. Profits come from producing these labeling materials and data-rich tags and selling them to packaging converters and brand owners worldwide.
AXTA: Axalta formulates liquid and powder coatings that protect and color cars, trucks, and industrial equipment. The Performance Coatings unit sells refinish paints to body shops and industrial coatings to makers of appliances, buildings, and rail cars. The Mobility Coatings unit supplies primers, basecoats, and clearcoats to global auto makers for new vehicle production. The company earns money by blending pigments, resins, and additives into durable paints and selling them through distributors and long-term supply contracts.
BALL: Ball Corporation shapes aluminum cans for soft drinks, beer, and energy drinks across the Americas, Europe, and South America. It also builds satellites, sensors, and aerospace systems for U.S. defense and space agencies. Most revenue comes from long-term supply deals with beverage makers that need lightweight, recyclable containers. The company earns money by rolling and forming aluminum into cans at high-volume plants and by designing and delivering space hardware under government contracts.
BLDR: Builders FirstSource sells lumber, engineered wood, windows, doors, trusses, and other building supplies to professional homebuilders. It operates distribution centers and plants that cut, pre-hang, and assemble roof and floor trusses, wall panels, and millwork. Revenue is linked to housing starts and repair-and-remodel demand across the United States. The company makes money by purchasing raw lumber and building components in bulk, adding value through fabrication, and reselling them to builders.
BWXT: BWX Technologies fabricates nuclear reactor components and naval nuclear fuel for U.S. Navy submarines and aircraft carriers. It also makes commercial nuclear steam generators, fuel, and medical radioisotopes. The services arm provides engineering, maintenance, and environmental cleanup for government nuclear sites. Profits are driven by long-term defense contracts and sales of nuclear equipment and services to power utilities and medical firms.
CCJ: Cameco is one of the worldâs largest publicly traded uranium producers. It operates high-grade mines in Canadaâs Athabasca Basin and markets uranium concentrates globally under long-term contracts and in the spot market. Its Fuel Services division refines uranium concentrate at Blind River, converts it to UF6 and UO2 at Port Hope, and fabricates CANDU fuel bundles, while a 49% stake in Westinghouse Electric Company provides exposure to reactor technology and nuclear-services demand. Profits come mainly from uranium sales volumes and prices, plus conversion service fees.
CSL: Carlisle makes rubber and thermoplastic roofing membranes, insulation boards, and metal panels for commercial buildings. Its Weatherproofing unit sells waterproofing coatings, air barriers, and architectural metal for walls and foundations. The Interconnect Technologies arm produces wire harnesses and fiber-optic cables for aircraft and medical devices, while Fluid Technologies supplies paint spray equipment. Profits come from manufacturing these construction and engineered products and selling them through distributors and direct contracts.
CARR: Carrier Global designs and manufactures heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning equipment such as chillers, furnaces, and air handlers. It also sells refrigerated transport units for trucks, trailers, and shipping containers that keep food and medicine cold. The Fire & Security unit provides smoke detectors, fire suppression systems, and electronic access controls. The company earns revenue by selling these climate and safety products and by providing parts and maintenance contracts.
CC: Chemours produces titanium dioxide pigment that gives brightness and opacity to paints, plastics, and paper. It also makes refrigerants and propellants under the Opteon brand for air conditioners, heat pumps, and aerosols. The Advanced Performance Materials unit supplies fluoropolymers and ion exchange membranes used in semiconductors, fuel cells, and chemical processing. Profits come from manufacturing these fluorine-based chemicals and selling them to industrial and consumer product makers.
CLH: Clean Harbors collects, treats, and disposes of hazardous waste from factories, refineries, and laboratories. It operates incinerators, landfills, and wastewater treatment plants and offers emergency spill response services. The Safety-Kleen unit recycles used motor oil into base oil and supplies parts-washer services and solvent recycling. Revenue is generated by charging fees for waste collection, treatment, and recycled oil products.
FIX: Comfort Systems USA installs and services heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and plumbing systems in commercial, institutional, and industrial buildings. Its crews design ductwork, set chillers and boilers, and integrate building automation controls. The company also provides maintenance contracts and energy retrofit projects after the initial construction. Money comes from mechanical contracting fees and recurring service revenue tied to the installed equipment base.
CTVA: Corteva breeds and sells corn, soybean, and other crop seeds under the Pioneer and Brevant brands. It also manufactures herbicides, insecticides, and fungicides that protect crops from weeds and pests. The company runs research centers to develop traits like drought tolerance and new modes of chemical action. Revenue is earned by selling high-yield seeds and crop protection chemicals to farmers around the world.
CCK: Crown Holdings manufactures aluminum and steel beverage cans for soda, beer, and energy drinks in the Americas, Europe, and Asia. Its Transit Packaging unit produces plastic strap, film, and steel drums that secure goods during shipping. The company signs multi-year supply agreements with large beverage brands that need lightweight, recyclable containers. Earnings come from forming metal into cans at high-speed plants and selling packaging equipment and consumables to industrial customers.
CW: Curtiss-Wright makes actuation systems, sensors, and surface treatment services for commercial aircraft and industrial equipment. Its defense electronics unit builds embedded computing modules, flight test instrumentation, and data links for missiles and military vehicles. The naval and power group supplies reactor coolant pumps, valves, and control systems for U.S. Navy submarines and nuclear power plants. Money comes from long-term defense contracts and sales of engineered components and services to aerospace, energy, and industrial customers.
DHI: D.R. Horton builds and sells single-family homes, townhomes, and condominiums across the United States. It buys land, develops lots, and constructs houses under brands such as Express, D.R. Horton, and Emerald. The Forestar segment buys raw land and develops finished lots that are sold to the homebuilding unit and other builders. The company earns revenue from home sales, land development margins, and mortgage, title, and insurance fees.
DOV: Dover makes industrial pumps, compressors, and bearings used in chemical processing and hygienic markets. It also sells fuel dispensers, underground storage hardware, and vehicle wash systems to gas stations and car wash operators. Other units provide marking and coding printers, food refrigeration cases, and waste handling equipment. Profits come from manufacturing these engineered products and selling aftermarket parts and services worldwide.
DD: DuPont produces semiconductor photoresists, CMP slurries, and circuit materials used in chip fabrication. It also makes Kevlar fiber, Tyvek protective material, and reverse-osmosis membranes for water filtration. The firm sells into electronics, construction, safety, and industrial markets after divesting several legacy businesses. Profits are generated by manufacturing these specialty materials and supplying them to chip makers, water utilities, and protective gear producers.
ETN: Eaton makes circuit breakers, switchgear, and uninterruptible power systems that manage electricity in buildings and data centers. Its Electrical units also sell industrial control drives and wiring devices. The aerospace arm supplies hydraulic pumps, fuel systems, and hoses for aircraft, while the vehicle and eMobility units produce engine valves, transmissions, and power distribution units for cars and trucks. Profits come from designing these power management products and selling replacement parts and services under long-term agreements.
ECL: Ecolab sells cleaning and sanitizing chemicals, water treatment programs, and digital monitoring tools to factories, hotels, and restaurants. Its Healthcare and Life Sciences unit provides sterile drapes, surgical fluids, and disinfectants for hospitals and drug makers. The Pest Elimination business controls rodents and insects in food plants and retail stores. Revenue is earned through chemical sales, equipment leases, and service contracts that reduce water use and improve hygiene.
EME: EMCOR designs and installs electrical, mechanical, and plumbing systems for commercial buildings, data centers, and hospitals. Its building services arm provides maintenance, energy retrofit, and facility management for HVAC, fire protection, and power systems. The industrial services unit offers refinery turnaround work, heat exchanger cleaning, and scaffolding for energy plants. The company makes money from construction project contracts and recurring service agreements across the United States and the United Kingdom.
FAST: Fastenal distributes bolts, screws, nuts, and other fasteners to manufacturers and construction firms through thousands of vending machines and branches. It also supplies safety gloves, masks, and janitorial products, plus tools, cutting fluids, and electrical supplies. The company stocks products in regional hubs and uses its own truck fleet for daily delivery. Revenue is earned by buying these industrial supplies in bulk and reselling them under supply contracts and point-of-use vending programs.
FTV: Fortive makes test and measurement instruments such as Fluke multimeters, Tektronix oscilloscopes, and Gems sensors. Its Precision Technologies unit produces torque tools, laser trackers, and gas analyzers for factories and labs. The Advanced Healthcare Solutions arm supplies patient monitoring, sterilization, and operating room workflow software to hospitals. Profits are generated by selling these instruments, software subscriptions, and calibration services worldwide.
FBIN: Fortune Brands Innovations sells Moen faucets, House of Rohl sinks, and Aqualisa shower systems for kitchens and bathrooms. Its Outdoors & Security unit offers Therma-Tru doors, Larson storm doors, and Master Lock padlocks and safes. The company markets these branded products through home centers, wholesalers, and online channels in North America and Europe. Profits come from manufacturing and sourcing these water, outdoor living, and security products and selling them to remodelers and homeowners.
GTES: Gates Industrial molds rubber and polyurethane belts that transfer power in engines, conveyors, and industrial machines. Its Fluid Power unit makes hydraulic hoses and fittings that carry oil and water in construction and agricultural equipment. The company sells through distributors and original equipment makers across automotive, industrial, and off-highway markets. Revenue is earned by producing these motion control components and supplying replacement parts for the installed base.
GEV: GE Vernova builds gas turbines, steam turbines, and generators that produce electricity for utilities and industrial plants. Its renewable energy business designs onshore and offshore wind turbines and grid equipment. Service teams provide long-term maintenance contracts and digital monitoring for installed power assets. Revenue comes from selling new equipment and earning service fees over the life of the turbines and generators.
GWW: Grainger distributes maintenance, repair, and operating supplies like motors, safety gloves, and fasteners to factories, hospitals, and government agencies. Its High-Touch Solutions segment uses sales reps, branches, and inventory management systems to serve large customers in North America. The Endless Assortment unit runs Zoro and MonotaRO websites that list millions of items for small businesses. Profits come from buying MRO products in bulk and reselling them with same-day shipping and inventory services.
GPK: Graphic Packaging converts paperboard into folding cartons, cups, and foodservice containers for cereal, beverages, and quick-serve restaurants. It also operates mills that make coated recycled and solid bleached paperboard used in its own converting plants and sold to third parties. Integrated production lets the company control raw material costs and ensure supply. Profits come from printing and forming paperboard into custom packaging and selling it under multi-year contracts to consumer goods companies.
HON: Honeywell makes avionics, environmental control systems, and auxiliary power units for commercial and military aircraft. It also sells building automation software, fire alarms, and security controls for offices, hospitals, and data centers. The Performance Materials and Technologies unit produces process automation systems, catalysts, and refrigerants, while Safety and Productivity Solutions offers gas detectors, gloves, and barcode scanners. Profits come from selling these hardware and software products and from aftermarket service contracts.
HWM: Howmet Aerospace casts nickel and titanium turbine blades and vanes for jet engines and industrial gas turbines. It also forges aluminum and titanium fasteners used to join airframe panels and engines. The engineered structures unit supplies titanium fuselage parts, and the forged wheels unit makes aluminum wheels for heavy trucks. Profits come from producing these metal components and signing long-term supply agreements with aerospace and transportation customers.
HUBB: Hubbell manufactures wiring devices, lighting fixtures, and cable management systems used in commercial and industrial buildings. Its Utility Solutions unit makes smart meters, transformers, and connectors for electric, water, and gas utilities. The company sells through distributors and direct utility bids across North America. Revenue is generated by producing these electrical and grid products and supplying replacement parts.
IFF: IFF blends flavors for beverages, dairy, and snacks and mixes fragrance oils for perfumes, detergents, and candles. Its Health & Biosciences unit makes probiotics, enzymes, and food cultures, while Pharma Solutions supplies cellulosics that bind and coat tablets. The company works with consumer goods firms to create custom taste, smell, and texture profiles. Revenue is earned by formulating these specialty ingredients and selling them under multi-year supply agreements.
IR: Ingersoll Rand makes rotary screw air compressors, vacuum pumps, and blowers that power tools and factory processes. The Precision and Science Technologies unit builds diaphragm pumps, medical compressors, and dosing systems for laboratories and food plants. The company sells through distributors and direct accounts with service contracts and parts. Profits come from equipment sales and recurring aftermarket parts and maintenance.
INGR: Ingredion processes corn, tapioca, and potatoes into starches, sweeteners, and plant proteins used in beverages, bakery, and pet food. Its North America plants grind corn into dextrose, glucose, and high-fructose corn syrup. Facilities in South America, Asia-Pacific, and EMEA make specialty starches, texturizers, and stevia sweeteners for local markets. Profits come from converting crops into value-added ingredients and selling them to food and industrial customers.
IP: International Paper turns southern pine logs and recycled boxes into containerboard and corrugated packaging for e-commerce, food, and beverage shipments. It also produces fluff pulp used in diapers and hygiene products. Mills are integrated with box plants to lower costs and secure fiber supply. Revenue is generated by selling containerboard, boxes, and pulp under supply contracts with brand owners and converters.
JCI: Johnson Controls installs and services HVAC, fire, and security systems in commercial buildings and campuses. Its Global Products unit manufactures York chillers, Tyco sprinklers, and Metasys building automation controllers. Regional Building Solutions units design projects and provide maintenance across North America, EMEA, Latin America, and Asia-Pacific. The company earns revenue from equipment sales, installation contracts, and long-term service agreements.
LEN: Lennar buys land, develops lots, and builds single-family homes, townhomes, and condominiums across the United States. It sells under brands like Lennar, Everything's Included, and WCI Communities. The financial services arm provides mortgages, title insurance, and property insurance to buyers. Profits come from selling completed homes and capturing fee income from the related financing services.
LII: Lennox International makes gas furnaces, air conditioners, and heat pumps for homes in North America. It also builds rooftop units and variable refrigerant flow systems for offices, schools, and retail stores. The Refrigeration segment supplies condensing units and display cases for supermarkets and cold storage. Revenue is earned by manufacturing these HVAC and refrigeration products and selling replacement parts and maintenance contracts.
LIN: Linde separates air into oxygen, nitrogen, and argon and produces hydrogen and carbon dioxide for steel, chemical, and food customers. It operates pipelines and on-site plants and delivers liquefied gases by truck. The engineering arm designs and builds cryogenic and hydrogen plants for third parties. Profits come from long-term gas supply contracts and equipment sales.
MLM: Martin Marietta quarries granite, limestone, and sand and crushes them into aggregates used in roads, bridges, and buildings. It also sells ready-mix concrete, asphalt, and cement in select markets. The Magnesia Specialties unit processes magnesium oxide and magnesium hydroxide for steel and chemical customers. Revenue is earned by mining raw stone, processing it, and delivering it to construction projects.
MAS: Masco sells Delta and Hansgrohe faucets, showerheads, and bath hardware to home centers and wholesalers. It also makes Behr paint, Kilz primer, and Liberty cabinet hardware for DIY and professional painters. The company sources metal and plastic parts globally and finishes products in North America and Europe. Revenue is generated by marketing these branded plumbing and architectural products to remodelers and builders.
MOD: Modine makes air-source heat pumps, unit heaters, and data center cooling systems for commercial buildings. Its Performance Technologies unit produces charge-air coolers, radiators, and oil coolers for trucks, off-highway equipment, and power generation. The company operates manufacturing plants in North America, Europe, and Asia. Revenue is generated by designing thermal management products and supplying them to OEMs and building owners.
MHK: Mohawk Industries produces ceramic tile, luxury vinyl plank, laminate, carpet, and hardwood flooring for homes and commercial spaces. Its plants in the United States, Mexico, and Europe fire tile, extrude vinyl, and tuft carpet. The company sells through distributors, big-box stores, and its own retail outlets. Profits come from manufacturing flooring materials at scale and selling them under brands like Daltile, Pergo, and Marazzi.
NVT: nVent molds metal and plastic enclosures that protect electrical and electronic equipment in factories and data centers. It also sells cable trays, grounding bars, and fasteners that connect and secure wiring. The Thermal Management unit provides heat-tracing cables and controls that keep pipes and roofs from freezing. Profits come from manufacturing these electrical infrastructure products and selling them through distributors and OEMs.
OTIS: Otis designs, manufactures, and installs elevators, escalators, and moving walkways for residential and commercial buildings. After installation, it provides maintenance, modernization, and repair services under multi-year contracts. The global installed base exceeds two million units, creating recurring service demand. Profits come from selling new lift systems and earning steady fees for keeping them running.
OC: Owens Corning melts glass and spins it into fiberglass insulation batts and loose fill for homes and commercial buildings. It also laminates asphalt shingles and roofing accessories for residential roofs. The composites unit chops and weaves fiberglass strands into reinforcements for wind turbine blades, autos, and pipes. Revenue is earned by producing these building and industrial materials and selling them through distributors and retailers.
PKG: Packaging Corporation of America makes containerboard and corrugated boxes used to ship food, e-commerce goods, and industrial parts. Integrated mills produce linerboard and medium that feed its network of box plants. The paper segment manufactures office papers and market pulp. Profits come from converting trees and recycled fiber into boxes and paper and selling them under supply contracts.
PH: Parker-Hannifin manufactures hydraulic hoses, pneumatic cylinders, and fluid connectors that control motion in factory machines and mobile equipment. Its aerospace group supplies fuel, hydraulic, and flight control systems for commercial and military aircraft. The company operates plants worldwide and sells through distributors and direct OEM programs. Revenue comes from component sales, replacement parts, and long-term aerospace contracts.
PNR: Pentair builds pool pumps, filters, and heaters for residential swimming pools. It also makes water softeners, reverse-osmosis systems, and industrial pumps and valves for food, beverage, and energy plants. Products are sold through distributors, retailers, and OEMs worldwide. Revenue is earned by manufacturing these water and fluid control products and providing replacement cartridges and parts.
POOL: Pool Corporation distributes chlorine, pumps, filters, and cleaning equipment to pool service companies and builders. It also sells tile, decking, and concrete products used to construct new pools. Irrigation and landscape supplies such as drip tubing and lighting broaden the offering to contractors. Profits come from buying these outdoor living products in bulk and reselling them through its network of distribution centers.
PPG: PPG formulates paints, stains, and clearcoats for homes, cars - both OEM and Refinish, airplanes, and industrial machinery. The Performance Coatings unit sells architectural paints, marine coatings, and aerospace primers, while Industrial Coatings supplies auto OEM basecoats, packaging coatings, and powder coatings. The company operates research labs to adjust color and durability for each customer. Revenue is generated by blending pigments, resins, and solvents into coatings and selling them under long-term supply agreements.
PWR: Quanta Services designs, builds, and maintains electric transmission lines, substations, and distribution networks for utilities. It also installs solar farms, wind turbine foundations, and battery storage systems through its renewable energy unit. The underground segment constructs pipelines, gas distribution mains, and telecom fiber. Profits come from contracting services billed by labor hours and project milestones.
QXO: QXO is the largest publicly traded distributor of roofing and complementary exterior-building products in North America. QXO sources products from dozens of major manufacturers (CertainTeed, GAF, Carlisle, Owens Corning, etc.) and sells them to small- and mid-sized contractors.
RBC: RBC Bearings machines ball, roller, and plain bearings that reduce friction in aircraft engines, helicopters, and industrial gearboxes. It also produces precision gears, couplings, and shafts for defense, mining, and semiconductor equipment. Plants in the United States and Europe use forging, heat-treating, and grinding to meet tight tolerances. Profits come from selling these bearings and replacement parts under long-term supply agreements.
RRX: Regal Rexnord manufactures electric motors, gearboxes, and bearings used in conveyors, HVAC systems, and factory machines. Its Climate Solutions unit supplies blower motors and fans for residential and commercial air handlers. The Automation & Motion Control segment sells servo motors, linear actuators, and motion controllers for robotics and packaging lines. Revenue is generated by producing these power transmission products and selling spare parts and services.
RSG: Republic Services collects municipal solid waste and recyclables from homes and businesses using a fleet of collection trucks. It operates transfer stations, recycling centers, and landfills that process and dispose of the material. The Environmental Solutions unit treats hazardous waste, industrial liquids, and medical waste. Revenue is earned through collection fees, landfill tipping charges, and recycling commodity sales.
ROK: Rockwell Automation makes programmable logic controllers, variable-frequency drives, and industrial sensors that control factory machines. Its Software & Control unit sells FactoryTalk software, analytics, and edge devices for plant operations. The Lifecycle Services arm provides system integration, cybersecurity, and maintenance contracts. Revenue is earned by selling automation hardware, software subscriptions, and engineering services to manufacturers.
RPM: RPM International makes roof coatings, sealants, and concrete admixtures for commercial construction. The Consumer Group sells Rust-Oleum spray paint, DAP caulk, and wood stains through home centers. Performance Coatings supplies epoxy floor systems and marine coatings, while the Specialty Products unit formulates powder pigments and fireproofing. Profits come from blending chemicals into niche coatings and selling them through distributors and retailers.
SHW: Sherwin-Williams manufactures and sells architectural paint, stains, and industrial coatings. They do not do auto Refinish. Its Paint Stores Group runs company-owned stores that serve professional painters and homeowners in North America. The Consumer Brands Group supplies private-label paint to big-box retailers, while the Performance Coatings Group sells protective and marine coatings to factories and oil platforms. Profits come from producing coatings and operating a direct distribution network.
SW: Smurfit Westrock converts recycled and virgin fiber into linerboard and corrugated sheets, then prints and folds them into shipping boxes for food, e-commerce, and industrial goods. It also makes paperboard cartons for drinks, cosmetics, and frozen foods and sells uncoated kraft and containerboard to other converters. The company runs recycling plants that collect old boxes and feed its paper mills. Profits come from integrated production of paper and packaging sold under supply contracts to brand owners.
TTEK: Tetra Tech provides engineering and consulting services that clean water, manage waste, and restore ecosystems for U.S. federal agencies. It designs water treatment plants, coastal resilience projects, and renewable energy systems for commercial and international clients. Work is billed by the hour under cost-plus and fixed-price contracts. Revenue is earned from professional service fees and project management margins.
TOL: Toll Brothers buys land and builds luxury single-family homes, townhomes, and condos in affluent U.S. markets. It offers design upgrades like custom kitchens and stone facades that raise selling prices. The company also develops apartment communities and owns mortgage, title, and insurance subsidiaries. Profits come from home sales and fee income on financing and joint-venture projects.
BLD: TopBuild installs fiberglass and spray foam insulation, fireplaces, and gutters in new single-family and commercial buildings. Its TruTeam branch crews work directly with homebuilders, while the Service Partners unit distributes insulation and related products to contractors. The firm buys large volumes of insulation from major manufacturers and marks up the material and labor. Earnings come from installation fees and product sales tied to the pace of residential and commercial construction.
TT: Trane Technologies manufactures chillers, rooftop units, heat pumps, and air handlers that heat and cool commercial buildings and homes. It sells under the Trane and American Standard brands in North America, Europe, and Asia. The company also provides building automation controls, parts, and service agreements. Profits come from equipment sales and long-term service contracts that keep HVAC systems running.
TDG: TransDigm designs and manufactures pumps, valves, ignition systems, and cockpit controls installed on commercial and military aircraft. It also produces latches, seat belts, and lavatory hardware that airlines replace during maintenance. Most parts are proprietary and sold as spares over the life of each aircraft program. Revenue is earned from initial OEM sales and recurring aftermarket shipments to airlines and defense depots.
TREX: Trex extrudes recycled polyethylene and wood fibers into composite decking boards and railing systems for outdoor living spaces. The boards resist rot and fading better than treated lumber and are sold through home centers and contractors. The commercial unit fabricates custom railing and staging systems for stadiums and arenas. Revenue is generated by manufacturing decking and railing products and selling them to distributors and builders.
VLTO: Veralto makes water analyzers, filtration membranes, and chemical dosing pumps that help treat drinking water and wastewater. It also sells inkjet coders, labelers, and vision inspection systems that mark and check food, beverage, and pharmaceutical packages. The company earns recurring revenue from replacement cartridges, reagents, and service contracts. Profits come from supplying these instruments and consumables to municipalities and manufacturers.
VRT: Vertiv designs and builds uninterruptible power supplies, thermal management units, and racks that keep data centers and telecom sites running. It sells prefabricated modular data center rooms and monitoring software that tracks power and cooling performance. Service technicians provide installation, preventive maintenance, and spare parts. Profits come from equipment sales and recurring service contracts across the Americas, Asia, and EMEA regions.
VMC: Vulcan Materials blasts and crushes limestone, granite, and gravel into construction aggregates used in roads, bridges, and buildings. It also mixes asphalt and ready-mixed concrete near its quarries to serve paving and structural projects. A small calcium business sells ground limestone to animal feed and chemical customers. Revenue is earned by mining stone, processing it, and delivering it to job sites.
WM: Waste Management collects household and commercial trash with its truck fleet and hauls it to company-owned transfer stations and landfills. It also sorts paper, plastic, and metals at recycling facilities and sells the recovered materials. Landfill gas is captured and converted into electricity and renewable natural gas that is sold to utilities and trucking fleets. Profits come from collection fees, landfill tipping charges, and commodity sales.
WCN: Waste Management collects household and commercial trash with its truck fleet and hauls it to company-owned transfer stations and landfills. It also sorts paper, plastic, and metals at recycling facilities and sells the recovered materials. Landfill gas is captured and converted into electricity and renewable natural gas that is sold to utilities and trucking fleets. Profits come from collection fees, landfill tipping charges, and commodity sales.
WCC: WESCO buys wire, circuit breakers, lighting, and data cabling from thousands of manufacturers and distributes them to contractors, utilities, and factories. Its Electrical & Electronic Solutions unit serves industrial MRO and OEM customers, while Communications & Security Solutions supplies fiber, switches, and cameras for data networks. The Utility & Broadband segment provides power cable, transformers, and smart-grid gear to electric utilities and broadband operators. Revenue is earned by aggregating products, managing inventory, and delivering them just-in-time to job sites.
WWD: Woodward engineers fuel nozzles, actuators, and control systems that manage combustion in jet engines and industrial gas turbines. Its aerospace unit sells these components to aircraft makers and provides spares to airlines. The industrial unit supplies control valves and ignition systems for power plants, trucks, and construction equipment. Revenue is earned from original equipment sales and aftermarket parts and service.
XYL: Xylem makes submersible pumps, mixers, and filtration systems that move and treat water in municipal and industrial plants. Its Applied Water unit sells booster pumps, valves, and heat exchangers for commercial buildings and irrigation. The Measurement & Control Solutions segment provides smart meters, networked sensors, and software that detect leaks and bill water use. Profits come from selling these pumps and digital products and providing parts and service contracts.
GE: Global diversified industrial leader across aviation, healthcare, power, and renewable energy.
FERG: Leading distributor of plumbing and HVAC supplies to contractors and builders in North America.
CNM: Distributor of waterworks and infrastructure products for municipalities and contractors.
JHX: Manufacturer of fiber-cement siding and building products in North America and Europe.
FLS: Flowserve is one of the worlds largest providers of industrial flow control systemsmanufacturing and servicing pumps, valves, seals, and automation solutions for sectors like power, oil & gas, chemical processing, and water management. Headquartered in Irving, Texas, it serves clients globally through a mix of OEMs, distributors, and end-users.
CR: Industrial manufacturer delivering flow control systems across aerospace, healthcare, electronics, and process industries including nuclear.
BE: Bloom Energy is an American clean energy company that designs, manufactures, and installs solid oxide fuel cell systemscalled Energy Serversthat generate electricity onsite using natural gas, biogas, or hydrogen without combustion, offering reliable, lower-carbon power for commercial, industrial, and data center applications.
MIR: Provider of radiation detection, measurement, and imaging solutions for healthcare, nuclear, and defense sectors.
DE: Deere & Company designs and manufactures tractors, combines, sprayers, and precision agriculture systems under the John Deere brand. Its Construction & Forestry unit produces loaders, excavators, and roadbuilding equipment, while the Financial Services arm provides credit and leasing to dealers and customers. The Precision Ag platform integrates GPS guidance, sensors, and software that optimize planting, fertilizing, and harvesting. Revenue is generated by selling equipment, parts, and technology solutions to farmers, contractors, and forestry operators worldwide.
AGCO: AGCO is a global leader in agricultural machinery and precision technology, designing, manufacturing, and distributing tractors, combines, sprayers, tillage, and smart farming systems under brands like Fendt, Massey Ferguson, Valtra, and PTx. The company focuses on serving farmers and OEMs with sustainable, technology-enhanced equipment.
CAT: Caterpillar designs and manufactures construction and mining equipment, diesel and natural gas engines, industrial gas turbines, and rail locomotives through Progress Rail. The business operates through Construction Industries, Resource Industries, and Energy & Transportation, with Financial Products providing retail and dealer financing. Products include excavators, loaders, dozers, trucks, drills, generator sets, and marine and oilfield power systems. Revenue comes from selling equipment, parts, and services through a global independent dealer network, with growing contributions from digital fleet management and lifecycle support for construction, mining, energy, marine, and rail customers.
CMI: Cummins designs and manufactures diesel, natural gas, hybrid, and battery-electric powertrains along with key components such as turbochargers, filtration, fuel systems, aftertreatment, transmissions, and axles through Meritor. The company operates through Engine, Components, Distribution, and Power Systems, with Accelera focused on zero-emissions technologies including batteries, e-axles, fuel cells, and electrolyzers. Cummins serves on-highway truck and bus OEMs, industrial equipment makers, marine and rail operators, and standby power customers. Revenue is generated by engines, components, and generator sets sold to OEMs and fleets, plus aftermarket parts, service, and long-term support contracts.
GNRC: Designer and manufacturer of backup generators and energy storage solutions for residential and commercial users.
SWK: Global provider of tools, hardware, and security products under brands like Stanley and DeWalt.
OKLO: Oklo develops compact fast microreactors intended to provide carbon‑free baseload power for data centers and industrial customers. The model centers on selling electricity via long‑term power purchase agreements and deploying reactors at customer sites. The company is early‑stage; commercialization depends on regulatory approvals and fuel availability.
SMR: NuScale Power designs small modular nuclear reactors (light‑water technology) and provides related engineering, licensing, and project services. Revenue today is primarily services‑ and milestone‑based; large‑scale deployment depends on customer projects reaching construction and receiving regulatory approvals.
